acute_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Acute
acute_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: It was classified into Category 1 from ErC50=0.074mg/L of the algae (Green Algae) (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data, 1995).

acute_toxicity_dermal.rationale: Based on the absence of mortality at the highest dose of 2,000mg/kg observed in the dermal studies with rats (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1995)).

acute_toxicity_inhalation_dust.hazard_name: Acute toxicity Inhalation: Dusts and mists
acute_toxicity_inhalation_dust.rationale: Based on the rat LC50 (inhalation route) value of 0.68mg/L (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1995)).

acute_toxicity_inhalation_gas.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is a solid according to the GHS definition and inhalation of its gas is not expected.

acute_toxicity_oral.rationale: Based on the rat LD50 (oral route) value of 97mg/kg (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1995)).

carcinogenicity.rationale: There was no treatment-related increase in tumor incidence observed in mouse and rat carcinogenicity studies (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1995)).

chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Long-term
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_statement: Very toxic to aquatic life with long lasting effects
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Since acute toxicity was Category 1 and there was no rapidly degrading (BIOWIN), and since there wasbio-accumulation (log Kow=4 (PHYSPROP Database, 2005)), it was classified into Category 1.

corrosive_to_metals.rationale: Test methods applicable to solid substances with melting point of >55degC are not available (melting point: 202.7-203.0degC (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (2001))).

explosives.rationale: Containing no chemical groups with explosive properties

flammable_gases.hazard_name: Flammable gases including chemically unstable gases
flammable_gases.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

flammable_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

gases_under_pressure.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

germ_cell_mutagenicity.rationale: Based on negative data on in vitro reverse mutagenicity tests and chromosome aberration tests, and in vivo micronucleus tests on mouse bone marrow cells (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1995)).

oxidizing_gases.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

oxidizing_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

oxidizing_solids.rationale: Classification not possible due to lack of data, though being organic compounds containing oxygen (but not chlorine and fluorine) bound to the elements other than carbon and hydrogen

pyrophoric_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

reproductive_toxicity.hazard_statement: Suspected of damaging fertility or the unborn child
reproductive_toxicity.rationale: Based on the evidence of reduced mating frequency (F1) and reduced numbers of litters/live borns at doses causing reduced body weight gains, observed in rat 2-generation reproduction studies (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1995)). Since it cannot be clearly demonstrated that these findings of reproductive effects are secondary, the substance is classified into Category 2 from the viewpoint of safety.

self_reactive_substances.rationale: Classification not possible due to lack of data, though being sulfonyls, containing chemical groups with self-reactive properties.

serious_eye_damage_irritation.rationale: In rabbit eye irritation tests, mild conjunctival redness was noted with a mean Draize score of 0.44. The reactions resolved by Day 3 (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1995)). The substance is thus considered non-irritating.

skin_corrosion_irritation.rationale: Based on no evidence of irritation observed in rabbit skin irritation tests, reported in Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1995).

skin_sensitizer.rationale: Two sensitization studies in guinea pigs using the Maximization method yielded inconsistent results (positive rates of 20% and 0%) (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1995, 1996)), which do not allow the presence or absence of sensitization to be determined.

substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures which, in contact with water, emit flammable gases
substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.rationale: Containing no metals or metalloids (B, Si, P, Ge, As, Se, Sn, Sb, Te, Bi, Po, At)

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Repeated exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_statement:
Cause damage to organs through prolonged or repeated exposure (nervous system)
May cause damage to organs through prolonged or repeated exposure (thyroid, liver)
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.rationale: In rat repeated dose toxicity studies, clinical signs and symptoms including increased absolute/relative weights of the liver and thyroid gland, tendency of the increased incidence of hypertrophy/hyperplasia in thyroid gland cystic epitelial cells, and increased panlobular lipogenesis (males) were found. In dogs, evidence of reduced activity, tremors, convulsions and muscular fasciculations was reported (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1995)). These effects were observed at dosing levels within the guidance value ranges for Category 1 (nervous system) and Category 2 (liver and thyroid gland).

systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Single exposure
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.rationale: In rat single dose toxicity studies, clinical signs and symptoms including clonic convulsions, piloerection, abnormal gait, diarrhea, decreased respiration rate, lethargy, coma, tremors and reduced locomotor activity were reported (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1995)). These effects were observed at dosing levels within the guidance value ranges for Category 1.
